results.content:
James is an exceptional instructor who not only has deep technical expertise, but also a true passion for teaching. 

Coming into the course I did not know much about MS Visual Studio Code, outside of the fact that it existed.  After taking James course I feel as if I have comprehensive understanding of the core capabilities of MS Visual Studio Code as well as an approach on how to navigate the MS Visual Studio Code site to get answers to any questions I may have in the future. 

Prior to this course I was using NotePad++ for text editing, now I can't see a world in which I use that application again. I would highly recommend this course to all who are interested in learning MS Visual Studio Code for the first time as well as those who are looking for a refresher. 

Thanks for an exceptional learning experience James!

response.content: Thank you so much for the kind words!
response.content_html: Thank you so much for the kind words!

results.content: presentations/lectures are not well planned, ofter filled with errors or mistakes, and very little preparation for the student. I spent a lot of time just figuring out what he had done to get to a certain place in VSCode. He seems to be typing command on the keyboard without saying what he is doing, to the display jumps to something else, after which he says ... "oops, I guess that is not right, let me backtrack." Often the shortcuts don't work b/c he has had us previously install some other module that overrides the default shortcuts. Frustrating. And the examples are extremely incomplete. Not at all clear where to find sample code, and even those examples were not tailored to the course.

response.content: Very honest feedback. I appreciate that! The intro video in the beginning has a link to the GitHub repository with section details and sample code. For the most part you don’t need specific code to work with. It’s more about the editor and less about the specific project. I try to cover shortcuts early so that I don’t have to explain as I go later on. It’s also somewhat impossible for me to gauge everyone’s shortcut setups. I started from scratch on my environment with no extra overrides other than what we do in the class. I’m wondering what shortcuts specifically you had issues with? Anyways thanks again for taking the course and the honest feedback!
response.content_html: Very honest feedback. I appreciate that! The intro video in the beginning has a link to the GitHub repository with section details and sample code. For the most part you don’t need specific code to work with. It’s more about the editor and less about the specific project. I try to cover shortcuts early so that I don’t have to explain as I go later on. It’s also somewhat impossible for me to gauge everyone’s shortcut setups. I started from scratch on my environment with no extra overrides other than what we do in the class. I’m wondering what shortcuts specifically you had issues with? Anyways thanks again for taking the course and the honest feedback!

results.content:
I came for the Source Control and the VS Code Live Share but I learned so much more than I expected about VS Code. I've been using it for a few months without really exploring the setup options or even very many of the features but James's course makes it easy to get familiar and highlights just how user friendly VS Code is. If you're like me and can't really stand reading the documentation, be assured that you will feel far more at ease with VS Code, whether you're coming to it from another application or, if you're like me and you're just starting out with coding.
The modules in Section 7 were mostly beyond my comprehension because I don't know any JavaScript, but I was still able to take notes for that time in the future when I *do* have that knowledge. So many great resources, simple instructions, and no wasted time - James is efficient and easy to follow. He's also really accessible if you have questions; I've bugged him on here and on Twitter and his responses have been prompt.

results.content:
This is one the few Udemy courses I've actually fully completed!  James walks you through things very clearly and covers a lot in this course!

I only deducted half a star because there are still some minor areas that can be improved but it is pretty good as is already.

Each of the videos where James explain some VS Code shortcuts could use a quick visual recap at the end (Mac and Windows) because it'll take a while until one can memorise all the shortcuts.  Maybe even a shortcut cheat sheet with only those shortcuts James introduced?  The key binding inside VS Code and the official cheat sheet is just too overwhelming.

I truly valued James sharing his favourite extensions, but some of the extensions seem to overlap too much e.g. 2 extensions to color-code brackets, or EditorConfig, Prettier, ESLint and TSLin which seem to be mainly either/or ... just one recommendation would've sufficed for beginners to get started.

James has already completely updated the course since I purchased it so kudos to him ... but things change quickly and the TSLint bit is unfortunately already deprecated (which again to be fair to James, he has already acknowledged).

Anyhow, I would recommend if you want to learn how VS Code can help you speed up development!

results.content:
I have already downloaded and used VS Code to some extent, but I prefer to watch every lesson in case I missed something when I installed it.

I'm now half way through and so far the course has demonstrated just how flexible VS Code is and how easy it can be to set it up exactly how you want it. I might go as far as to say that you could spend way too much time messing with settings and themes and extensions etc. The lectures really demonstrate that very well.

After completing the course I'm pleased with it. I intend to use VS Code for other languages so I felt that the web dev parts of the lessons were a bit lost on me, but I appreciate that the principles of each will be similar.

I found the course to be very comprehensive in covering each main aspect of VS Code and has given me enough to feel confident in starting to develop fully in VS Code.
TIP: The videos can be quite quick, so have a notebook handy and jot down the interesting points. When the video finishes, pause, open VS Code and try it out. Then come back to video to review if you need further help.

results.content: This was a really great course teaching how to use keyboard shortcuts, Emmet, adding extensions for improved functionality, integrating Git, debugging and the live share was very interesting. I'd really recommend this course for anyone who wants to learn coding. There are a lot of other courses that are using Sublime, but VS Code really looks like it has more features. I will note that anyone who plans to take this course that James uses a Mac so on windows you'll need to look in the settings to correct some of the shortcuts, other than that it's all the same. Before you learn HTML/CSS and especially Javascript take this course first. Pause it when you get to git and watch a tutorial on YouTube to learn the basics of Git if you don't already know it. The Git interface in VS Code is easier than the terminal but you should have some general concept of how to use the terminal for Git first. Pause it on the debugging and take your Javascript course then come back and finish the section in this VS Code course on debugging. That's my advice.

results.content:
The one thing I would change about this course is that the instructor makes a lot of assumptions, such as assuming the student is familiar enough to follow when given an instruction without the 'how-to', and assuming the student's computer has everything already installed.

For example, a few times he used npm to install through the console. With no knowledge of what this is or how to get it, those steps were lost on me as the student. I'm not just converting to VS Code. I am using it to learn how to develop.

Having said this, I still gave the course 4 starts because there were a lot of positive take-aways that were very helpful. Overall, it is a good course and worth purchasing.

results.content:
I've been taking programming tutorials for about 8 months now.  I've used Unity, Android Studio, MonoDevelop, and a little bit of VS Code.  

I'm taking this class as a deep-dive into the VS Code text editor for the purposes of becoming a better programmer.  My experience with VS Code is a little different than MonoDevelop, so I could use a good 'tour' of VS Code.

Just started the class today.  Lesson 8 was where I started thinking, "Holy cr@p!  I can do that?"

Lesson 8 showed me A LOT of useful keyboard shortcuts to correct a lot of beginner things I've been doing, for example, easy ways to move and copy lines or change multiple variables at the same time.  

These are things that a 'learn to code by making video games' tutorial won't normally cover.  

Update 1:
Lesson 14 on Font Ligatures was pretty amazing.  I just finished Lesson 16 on Popular Extensions, which I found to be equally handy.  I'm really starting to LOVE VS Code.

One gripe, not necessarily about this class, but I wish it was something that is covered...

I'm programming in C#, and it took me FOREVER to figure out how to run C# code (several attempts and several hours).  I'm only 40% with this class, but we have not covered that yet.  

This instructor mostly shows examples in javascript or html, and VS Code demands a few more hoops to jump through when using C#.

With MonoDevelop (the editor I don't want to use anymore), one can simply run the C# code and a display will pop up.  In VS Code, there's a bunch of stuff to do with .NET Core first, and then the code will run using the built-in terminal (not as nice as a new window, but it works).  It's not 'click a Project.cs script and run'.   

I have not found a better solution yet.  I don't expect the C# issues to be covered in the scope of this class.  C# in VS Code is a learning curve in and of itself.  There are some short tutorials out there to search for help.

Still despite all of that, getting C# to run in VS Code was totally worth it.  This class will show you how to use VS Code to make your code look amazing and easy to read/share...but there's so much more than that!  

I'll use MonoDevelop again later if I have to (like for work)...the same way I'll use a Windows computer if I have to (like for work)...but after learning VS Code, why would anyone want to go back to MonoDevelop?  Like, if MonoDevelop was your first 'real car', VS Code is the Lamborghini you've been dreaming of.  Get ready.

More later...
results.content_html:

This instructor mostly shows examples in javascript or html, and VS Code demands a few more hoops to jump through when using C#.

With MonoDevelop (the editor I don't want to use anymore), one can simply run the C# code and a display will pop up. In VS Code, there's a bunch of stuff to do with .NET Core first, and then the code will run using the built-in terminal (not as nice as a new window, but it works). It's not 'click a Project.cs script and run'.

I have not found a better solution yet. I don't expect the C# issues to be covered in the scope of this class. C# in VS Code is a learning curve in and of itself. There are some short tutorials out there to search for help.

Still despite all of that, getting C# to run in VS Code was totally worth it. This class will show you how to use VS Code to make your code look amazing and easy to read/share...but there's so much more than that!

I'll use MonoDevelop again later if I have to (like for work)...the same way I'll use a Windows computer if I have to (like for work)...but after learning VS Code, why would anyone want to go back to MonoDevelop? Like, if MonoDevelop was your first 'real car', VS Code is the Lamborghini you've been dreaming of. Get ready.

More later...
